instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Got an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in today after not seeing any for a while <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. History as follows:
Came In dead - customer claims tried to change battery to fix macbook - still dead.
I open it and find a ton of flux on the bios chip, also notice <CHIP>U3990</CHIP> has been removed and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> is not soldered on straight. I go ahead and replace <CHIP>U3990</CHIP> from a donor board, realign <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> and then proceed to try and power up - no power still, I checked PPBUS which was at 0.8v, replaced the ISL which brought PPBUS back and board was powering up but no display so having known the BIOS chip has been messed around with before I pulled it to reprogram, found BIOS chip itself completely dead wouldnt even read in my programmer so i've programmed a new BIOS chip and soldered onto the board. 
Board is now powering up but fans running on full speed - have done both SMC and PRAM resets but same, now loaded ASD which told me there is a problem with sensor TN1D - all other sensors pass. Out the board comes again and I put it in the ultrasonic and then try it again - now Apple ASD passes so I think great it's all fixed now, 1 minute later fans on it are running at full speed again and ASD (which was still booted up) reporting a problem with TN1D sensor again which I believe is for the nVidia Chipset. 
Would like some pointers as to where to check now - it was working fine immediately after ultrasonic and board looks clean - no obvious signs of liquid damage other than the previous repairer had put thermal paste all over the place which i've cleaned off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Looks like bad MCP; is a 10 yo chip.

Reflow it with good flux, just to burn eventually accumulated crap underneath
Ultrasonic bath possibly didn't clean all first time; you can also repeat, after reflow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Reflowed and same behaviour assuming bad MCP at this point - given it's working fine otherwise would there be some way of routing some other sensor into <CHIP>U5535</CHIP> maybe the cpu one? 
Was thinking if I disconnected pins 2 and 3 of <CHIP>U5535</CHIP> and routed them to pins 2 and 3 of <CHIP>U5515</CHIP> I could trick the SMC into thinking the MCP is reading normally?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sensor Issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sensor Issue
threads.message:
Tried Removing <CHIP>U5535</CHIP> - same behavior also tried routing the CPU sensor into <CHIP>U5535</CHIP> which also resulted in the same error. At this point I am thinking either SMC issue or something is broken somewhere inside the board.

Luckily I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board which had just a mild case of liquid damage so i've managed to fix that one up for the customer instead - that one had a strange fault <SIGNAL>SMC_N_FOLLOW</SIGNAL> had a 30ohm short to ground and as such board would start but then shut off immediately - fixed by disconnecting pins 3 and 4 from <CHIP>U2594</CHIP> and pad 1 of <RESISTOR>R2598</RESISTOR> and then running a jumper wire between them which allowed it to work correctly.
